Genesis 1: God creates the heavens, the earth, light, sky, land, seas, vegetation, sun, moon, stars, sea creatures, birds, land animals, and humanity in six days. God declares everything He made to be very good and rests on the seventh day.
Genesis 2: God forms Adam from dust, plants the Garden of Eden, and places Adam there to work and care for it. God creates Eve from Adam's rib to be his helper and companion, establishing the first marriage.
Genesis 3: The serpent tempts Eve to eat from the forbidden tree, and she and Adam disobey God. God pronounces judgment on the serpent, the woman, and the man, then expels them from the Garden of Eden.
Genesis 4: Eve gives birth to Cain and Abel; Cain murders Abel out of jealousy when God accepts Abel's offering but not his own. God marks Cain and sends him away, and Adam and Eve have another son, Seth.
Genesis 5: This chapter traces the genealogy from Adam through Seth to Noah, recording the long lifespans of the early patriarchs. Enoch walks with God and is taken by God without experiencing death.
Genesis 6: Human wickedness spreads across the earth, grieving God's heart. God instructs Noah, a righteous man, to build an ark to survive the coming flood that will destroy all life on earth.
Genesis 7: Noah, his family, and pairs of every kind of animal enter the ark as commanded. The floodwaters come, covering the earth and destroying all living creatures outside the ark for forty days and nights.
Genesis 8: The floodwaters recede, and the ark comes to rest on the mountains of Ararat. Noah sends out a raven and then a dove to test if the earth has dried, and eventually exits the ark and builds an altar to worship God.
Genesis 9: God establishes a covenant with Noah, promising never again to destroy the earth by flood and giving the rainbow as a sign. God blesses Noah and his sons and gives them instructions for living, but Noah later becomes drunk and is shamed by his son Ham.
Genesis 10: This chapter records the table of nations, listing the descendants of Noah's three sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—who spread across the earth after the flood. These descendants become the various nations and peoples of the ancient world.
Genesis 11: Humanity attempts to build the Tower of Babel to make a name for themselves, but God confuses their language and scatters them across the earth. The chapter concludes with the genealogy from Shem to Abram, introducing the patriarch who will become Abraham.
Genesis 12: God calls Abram to leave his country and promises to make him into a great nation and bless all peoples through him. Abram travels to Canaan, builds altars to the Lord, but then goes to Egypt where he deceives Pharaoh about his wife Sarai.
Genesis 13: Abram and Lot separate due to their growing wealth and limited resources. Lot chooses the well-watered Jordan valley near Sodom, while Abram settles in Canaan where God reaffirms His promise of the land and countless descendants.
Genesis 14: Lot is captured during a war between regional kings, and Abram rescues him with his trained men. After the victory, Abram meets Melchizedek, king of Salem and priest of God Most High, and gives him a tenth of everything.
Genesis 15: God makes a formal covenant with Abram, promising him descendants as numerous as the stars and the land of Canaan. Abram believes God, and it is credited to him as righteousness.
Genesis 16: Sarai, unable to conceive, gives her servant Hagar to Abram to bear children. Hagar becomes pregnant and despises Sarai, leading to conflict, but an angel of the Lord finds Hagar in the wilderness and tells her to return and submit, promising her many descendants.
Genesis 17: God appears to Abram, changes his name to Abraham, and establishes the covenant of circumcision as a sign. God promises Abraham will be father of many nations, changes Sarai's name to Sarah, and promises she will bear a son named Isaac.
Genesis 18: The Lord appears to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre and promises Sarah will have a son within a year, despite her old age. Abraham intercedes for Sodom, bargaining with God to spare the city if righteous people can be found there.
Genesis 19: Two angels visit Lot in Sodom and rescue him and his family before destroying the wicked city with fire and sulfur. Lot's wife looks back and becomes a pillar of salt, and later Lot's daughters deceive him and become pregnant by him.
Genesis 20: Abraham travels to Gerar and again lies about Sarah being his sister, fearing he will be killed for his beautiful wife. God reveals the truth to King Abimelech in a dream, and Abraham prays for Abimelech's household to be healed.
Genesis 21: Sarah gives birth to Isaac as God promised, and Abraham circumcises him on the eighth day. Sarah demands that Abraham send away Hagar and Ishmael, which grieves Abraham, but God reassures him and provides for Hagar and her son in the wilderness.
Genesis 22: God tests Abraham by commanding him to sacrifice Isaac on Mount Moriah. Abraham obeys, but at the last moment God provides a ram as a substitute and reaffirms His covenant promises to Abraham.
Genesis 23: Sarah dies at age 127, and Abraham purchases the cave of Machpelah from Ephron the Hittite as a burial place. This is the first piece of the Promised Land that Abraham actually owns.
Genesis 24: Abraham sends his servant to find a wife for Isaac from his own relatives in Mesopotamia. The servant prays for guidance, meets Rebekah at a well, and she agrees to return with him to become Isaac's wife.
Genesis 25: Abraham dies and is buried beside Sarah, and Isaac inherits everything. Rebekah gives birth to twins, Esau and Jacob, who struggle even in the womb, and later Esau sells his birthright to Jacob for a bowl of stew.
Genesis 26: During a famine, Isaac goes to Gerar and, like his father, lies about his wife Rebekah. God blesses Isaac with great prosperity despite conflicts with the Philistines over wells, and God reaffirms His covenant promises to Isaac.
Genesis 27: Isaac prepares to bless Esau, but Rebekah helps Jacob deceive his father and steal the blessing intended for his older brother. When Esau discovers the deception, he weeps bitterly and vows to kill Jacob, so Rebekah sends Jacob away to her brother Laban.
Genesis 28: Jacob leaves for Haran and stops for the night at Bethel, where he dreams of a stairway to heaven with angels ascending and descending. God appears to Jacob and confirms the covenant promises, and Jacob makes a vow and sets up a memorial stone.
Genesis 29: Jacob arrives in Haran, meets Rachel at a well, and agrees to work seven years for Laban to marry her. Laban deceives Jacob by giving him Leah instead, and Jacob must work another seven years for Rachel.
Genesis 30: Rachel and Leah compete for Jacob's affection through childbearing, using their servants as surrogates. Jacob prospers in Laban's service, using selective breeding to increase his own flocks at Laban's expense.
Genesis 31: Jacob secretly flees from Laban with his wives, children, and possessions after God tells him to return to his homeland. Laban pursues but God warns him in a dream, and they make a covenant of peace before parting ways.
Genesis 32: Jacob prepares to meet Esau by sending gifts ahead and dividing his camp. At the Jabbok River, Jacob wrestles with God through the night, receives a blessing and a new name—Israel—and walks away with a limp.
Genesis 33: Jacob meets Esau with humility and fear, but Esau runs to embrace him and they are reconciled. Jacob settles near Shechem and builds an altar there.
Genesis 34: Dinah, Jacob's daughter, is violated by Shechem, who then wants to marry her. Simeon and Levi deceive the men of Shechem, kill them while they recover from circumcision, and plunder the city in revenge.
Genesis 35: God tells Jacob to return to Bethel, where He reaffirms the covenant and changes Jacob's name to Israel. Rachel dies giving birth to Benjamin, and Isaac dies and is buried by his sons Jacob and Esau.
Genesis 36: This chapter records the descendants of Esau, who becomes the father of the Edomites. The genealogy includes the chiefs and kings who came from Esau's line.
Genesis 37: Joseph, Jacob's favored son, dreams that his brothers will bow down to him, which increases their hatred. They sell Joseph into slavery and deceive Jacob into thinking Joseph was killed by a wild animal.
Genesis 38: Judah's son Er dies, and his second son Onan refuses to provide an heir for Er's widow Tamar. Tamar disguises herself as a prostitute and becomes pregnant by Judah, who later acknowledges that she is more righteous than he.
Genesis 39: Joseph serves Potiphar faithfully in Egypt and is blessed by God, but when Potiphar's wife falsely accuses him of assault, Joseph is thrown into prison. Even in prison, the Lord is with Joseph and grants him success.
Genesis 40: In prison, Joseph interprets dreams for Pharaoh's cupbearer and baker. The cupbearer is restored to his position as Joseph predicted, but forgets about Joseph for two years.
Genesis 41: Pharaoh has troubling dreams that his magicians cannot interpret, and the cupbearer finally remembers Joseph. Joseph interprets Pharaoh's dreams as predicting seven years of abundance followed by seven years of famine, and Pharaoh appoints Joseph as second in command over all Egypt.
Genesis 42: During the famine, Joseph's brothers come to Egypt to buy grain and bow before him, unknowingly fulfilling his earlier dreams. Joseph recognizes them but tests them by accusing them of being spies and holding Simeon as a hostage.
Genesis 43: The famine forces Jacob to send his sons back to Egypt with Benjamin. Joseph hosts them for a feast, and seeing Benjamin overwhelms him with emotion, though he still conceals his identity.
Genesis 44: Joseph tests his brothers by planting his silver cup in Benjamin's sack, then threatening to make Benjamin his slave. Judah pleads passionately for Benjamin's release, offering himself as a slave instead.
Genesis 45: Joseph can no longer control himself and reveals his identity to his brothers, assuring them that God sent him to Egypt to preserve life. Joseph instructs them to bring their father Jacob and all their households to live in Egypt.
Genesis 46: Jacob takes his entire family and travels to Egypt, offering sacrifices to God along the way. God appears to Jacob and promises to go with him and make him into a great nation, and Joseph is reunited with his father.
Genesis 47: Joseph presents his family to Pharaoh, and they settle in the land of Goshen. As the famine continues, Joseph manages Egypt's resources wisely, and the people sell their land to Pharaoh in exchange for food.
Genesis 48: Jacob blesses Joseph's two sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, crossing his hands to give the greater blessing to the younger son Ephraim. Jacob adopts these grandsons as his own, giving them inheritance rights equal to his other sons.
Genesis 49: Jacob gathers his twelve sons and prophesies over each one, describing their future and the character of their descendants. Jacob makes them promise to bury him in Canaan with his fathers, then dies.
Genesis 50: Joseph mourns his father, and the brothers travel to Canaan to bury Jacob as he requested. Joseph's brothers fear revenge after Jacob's death, but Joseph reassures them that God intended their evil actions for good, and he provides for them until his own death.
Exodus 1: The Israelites multiply greatly in Egypt, and a new Pharaoh who does not remember Joseph enslaves them. When harsh labor doesn't slow their growth, Pharaoh orders the Hebrew midwives to kill all newborn boys, but the midwives fear God and let the boys live.
Exodus 2: Moses is born and hidden by his mother, then adopted by Pharaoh's daughter and raised in the palace. As an adult, Moses kills an Egyptian who was beating a Hebrew slave, then flees to Midian where he marries Zipporah and becomes a shepherd.
Exodus 3: God appears to Moses in a burning bush and calls him to lead the Israelites out of Egypt. God reveals His name as 'I AM WHO I AM' and promises to be with Moses, giving him miraculous signs to perform before Pharaoh.
Exodus 4: Moses expresses his inadequacy and asks God to send someone else, which angers God, but God appoints Aaron to be Moses' spokesman. Moses returns to Egypt, and on the way Zipporah circumcises their son to save Moses from God's wrath.
Exodus 5: Moses and Aaron confront Pharaoh and demand that he let the Israelites go worship in the wilderness, but Pharaoh refuses and instead increases their workload. The Israelite foremen blame Moses for making their situation worse.
Exodus 6: God reassures Moses that He will deliver Israel with mighty acts of judgment and reaffirms His covenant promises. The genealogy of Moses and Aaron is recorded, tracing their lineage through Levi.
Exodus 7: God tells Moses he will be like God to Pharaoh, with Aaron as his prophet. Aaron's staff becomes a snake before Pharaoh, and though Pharaoh's magicians duplicate the sign, Aaron's staff swallows theirs, yet Pharaoh's heart remains hard.
Exodus 8: God sends plagues of frogs, gnats, and flies upon Egypt. Pharaoh repeatedly promises to let the Israelites go if Moses removes each plague, but each time hardens his heart and refuses after the plague is lifted.
Exodus 9: God sends plagues on the livestock, of boils on people and animals, and of devastating hail. Pharaoh's heart continues to harden despite seeing God's power, and he refuses to let the Israelites go.
Exodus 10: God sends locusts that devour every green plant left after the hail, and then brings thick darkness over Egypt for three days. Pharaoh repeatedly comes close to letting Israel go but always hardens his heart at the last moment.
Exodus 11: God tells Moses He will bring one final plague—the death of every firstborn in Egypt—which will compel Pharaoh to release the Israelites. Moses warns Pharaoh of this coming judgment, then leaves his presence in anger.
Exodus 12: God institutes the Passover, instructing Israel to mark their doorposts with lamb's blood so the destroyer will pass over their homes. At midnight God strikes down every firstborn in Egypt, and Pharaoh finally releases the Israelites, who plunder Egypt and depart that very night.
Exodus 13: God commands Israel to consecrate their firstborn and to observe the Feast of Unleavened Bread as a lasting ordinance. God leads the people by a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night, avoiding the Philistine route.
Exodus 14: Pharaoh pursues the Israelites with his army, trapping them against the Red Sea. Moses stretches out his hand, God parts the waters, and Israel crosses on dry ground, but when the Egyptians follow, the waters return and drown Pharaoh's army.
Exodus 15: Moses and the Israelites sing a song of victory celebrating God's deliverance and power. At Marah, the people grumble about bitter water, but God makes it sweet and promises to be their healer if they obey Him.
Exodus 16: The Israelites grumble about food, and God provides manna from heaven each morning and quail each evening. God tests the people by commanding them to gather only what they need each day, with a double portion on the sixth day, and to rest on the Sabbath.
Exodus 17: The people quarrel with Moses over lack of water at Rephidim, and God commands Moses to strike the rock, which produces water. The Amalekites attack Israel, and Joshua leads the battle while Moses' raised hands ensure victory.
Exodus 18: Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, brings Moses' wife and sons to him in the wilderness. Observing Moses' overwhelming workload, Jethro advises him to appoint capable leaders to judge the people, reserving only the difficult cases for himself.
Exodus 19: Israel arrives at Mount Sinai, and God proposes a covenant making them His treasured possession and a kingdom of priests. The people agree, and God descends on the mountain in thunder, lightning, and thick cloud, warning the people not to approach the mountain.
Exodus 20: God speaks the Ten Commandments directly to all the people, covering their relationship with Him and with one another. The people are terrified by God's presence and ask Moses to be their mediator, and God gives additional laws about worship.
Exodus 21: God gives Moses laws concerning Hebrew servants, personal injury, property damage, and restitution. These ordinances establish principles of justice and fair compensation for the community.
Exodus 22: God provides laws about property theft, damage to crops and livestock, and social responsibility. Additional laws address lending, treatment of the vulnerable, and the administration of justice.
Exodus 23: God commands justice in legal matters, care for the poor, observance of the Sabbath, and celebration of three annual festivals. God promises to send His angel before Israel to drive out the nations of Canaan, warning them not to worship foreign gods.
Exodus 24: Moses reads the Book of the Covenant to the people, and they affirm their commitment to obey God's words. Moses, Aaron, and seventy elders ascend the mountain and eat a covenant meal in God's presence, then Moses goes higher to receive the stone tablets.
Exodus 25: God instructs Moses to collect offerings from the people and gives detailed specifications for building the Ark of the Covenant, the table for the bread of the Presence, and the golden lampstand. These furnishings will reside in the tabernacle that God will command them to build.
Exodus 26: God provides detailed instructions for constructing the tabernacle, including the curtains, frames, crossbars, and the veil separating the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place. The design creates a portable sanctuary where God will dwell among His people.
Exodus 27: God gives specifications for the bronze altar for burnt offerings and the courtyard surrounding the tabernacle. God also commands Israel to bring pure olive oil for the lamps to burn continually before the Lord.
Exodus 28: God sets apart Aaron and his sons for the priesthood and gives detailed instructions for making sacred garments. The high priest's garments include an ephod, breastpiece with twelve stones representing the tribes, and other items that display glory and beauty.
Exodus 29: God prescribes the ordination ceremony for Aaron and his sons, involving washing, anointing with oil, and sacrifices. These rituals consecrate the priests and the tabernacle, enabling Aaron's family to serve as mediators between God and Israel.
Exodus 30: God gives instructions for the altar of incense, the bronze basin for washing, the sacred anointing oil, and the incense blend. God designates a half-shekel tax to support the tabernacle and emphasizes that the anointing oil and incense formula are sacred and not to be replicated for common use.
Exodus 31: God fills Bezalel and Oholiab with His Spirit, giving them skill and ability to craft all the tabernacle furnishings. God commands observance of the Sabbath as a sign of the covenant, then gives Moses the two stone tablets inscribed by God's own finger.
Exodus 32: While Moses is on the mountain, the people pressure Aaron to make a golden calf, which they worship as the god who brought them out of Egypt. God's anger burns against Israel, but Moses intercedes for them, and the Levites execute judgment on three thousand people who participated in the idolatry.
Exodus 33: God tells Moses to lead the people to the Promised Land but says He will not go with them because their stiff-necked nature would cause Him to destroy them. Moses pleads for God's presence, and God promises to go with them and let Moses see His glory.
Exodus 34: Moses ascends Mount Sinai again with two new stone tablets, and God reveals His character as compassionate, gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in love and faithfulness. God renews the covenant with Israel, and Moses' face radiates God's glory when he returns to the people.
Exodus 35: Moses gathers the people and reminds them to keep the Sabbath, then asks for offerings for the tabernacle. The people respond with such generosity that they bring more than enough materials, and skilled workers begin crafting the tabernacle and its furnishings.
Exodus 36: Bezalel, Oholiab, and other skilled craftsmen construct the tabernacle curtains and frames exactly as God commanded Moses. The people's offerings are so abundant that Moses must restrain them from bringing more.
Exodus 37: Bezalel makes the Ark of the Covenant with its mercy seat, the table for the bread of the Presence, the pure gold lampstand, and the altar of incense. Each item is crafted with meticulous detail according to God's specifications.
Exodus 38: The craftsmen build the bronze altar for burnt offerings, the bronze basin, and the courtyard with its posts and curtains. This chapter also records the inventory of materials used in constructing the tabernacle.
Exodus 39: The sacred garments for Aaron and his sons are completed exactly as God commanded, including the ephod, breastpiece, robe, and other priestly clothing. Moses inspects all the work and sees that it has been done according to God's instructions, and he blesses the workers.
Exodus 40: God commands Moses to set up the tabernacle on the first day of the first month. Moses does everything exactly as commanded, and when the work is complete, the glory of the Lord fills the tabernacle, and the cloud of God's presence guides Israel's travels from that day forward.
Leviticus 1: God instructs Moses on the regulations for burnt offerings, which represent complete dedication to the Lord. The offering can be from the herd, flock, or birds, depending on the worshiper's means, but must be a male without defect.
Leviticus 2: God provides instructions for grain offerings, which are gifts of thanksgiving and dedication made with fine flour, oil, and incense. No yeast or honey may be added, but all grain offerings must be seasoned with salt as a sign of God's covenant.
Leviticus 3: The fellowship offering is presented as a voluntary act of worship and thanksgiving, with the fat portions burned on the altar belonging to God. The worshiper and priests share in eating the meat, symbolizing peace and communion with God.
Leviticus 4: God establishes the sin offering for unintentional sins, with different requirements based on who sinned—the anointed priest, the whole community, a leader, or an individual. The blood is used for purification, and specific portions are burned while the rest is taken outside the camp.
Leviticus 5: Additional instructions for sin offerings cover specific situations including withholding testimony, touching unclean things, and making rash oaths. The guilt offering is introduced for sins requiring restitution, with provision made for the poor to offer birds instead of lambs.
Leviticus 6: God gives instructions for the guilt offering when someone sins by deception regarding property or finds lost property and lies about it. Additional regulations specify how priests are to handle the burnt offering, grain offering, and sin offering, including their portions.
Leviticus 7: God provides detailed instructions for the guilt offering and fellowship offering, including what portions belong to the priests. God forbids eating fat or blood, and outlines regulations for thank offerings, vow offerings, and freewill offerings.
Leviticus 8: Moses ordains Aaron and his sons as priests in an elaborate week-long ceremony involving washing, clothing them in priestly garments, anointing with oil, and offering sacrifices. The ordination establishes the priesthood that will serve as mediators between God and Israel.
Leviticus 9: On the eighth day, Aaron performs his first sacrifices as high priest for himself and the people. When Aaron blesses the people, the glory of the Lord appears to all the people, and fire comes from the Lord's presence to consume the burnt offering on the altar.
Leviticus 10: Aaron's sons Nadab and Abihu offer unauthorized fire before the Lord and are immediately consumed by fire from God's presence. God instructs Aaron and his remaining sons on how to conduct themselves as priests, including regulations about drinking alcohol and distinguishing between holy and common, clean and unclean.
Leviticus 11: God establishes dietary laws distinguishing between clean and unclean animals, specifying which land animals, water creatures, birds, and insects the Israelites may eat. These laws set Israel apart as holy and teach them to distinguish between the unclean and the clean.
Leviticus 12: God gives regulations for purification after childbirth, requiring a longer period of uncleanness for a daughter than a son. After the period of purification, the mother must bring a burnt offering and a sin offering to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
Leviticus 13: God provides detailed instructions for diagnosing infectious skin diseases and mildew in clothing. The priest examines and isolates suspicious cases, declaring people clean or unclean based on specific criteria to prevent the spread of disease within the community.
Leviticus 14: God establishes the cleansing ceremony for those healed from infectious skin diseases, involving birds, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, hyssop, and offerings. Instructions are also given for dealing with mildew in houses, including when a house must be torn down.
Leviticus 15: God gives laws concerning bodily discharges that cause ceremonial uncleanness, both for men and women. These regulations maintain the purity of the camp where God dwells among His people and require cleansing rituals before the person can rejoin the community.
Leviticus 16: God establishes the Day of Atonement, when the high priest enters the Most Holy Place once a year to make atonement for himself and all Israel. Two goats are used—one sacrificed as a sin offering and one sent into the wilderness as a scapegoat bearing Israel's sins.
Leviticus 17: God commands that all sacrifices must be brought to the tent of meeting and prohibits eating blood, which represents life and makes atonement. These laws prevent Israel from sacrificing to goat idols and emphasize that life belongs to God alone.
Leviticus 18: God commands Israel not to follow the practices of Egypt or Canaan, specifically prohibiting various forms of sexual immorality including incest, adultery, homosexual practice, and bestiality. Obedience to these laws will allow them to remain in the land, while disobedience will cause the land to vomit them out.
Leviticus 19: God calls Israel to be holy because He is holy, giving various laws covering justice, honesty, respect for parents and the elderly, caring for the poor, and loving one's neighbor as oneself. These practical commands demonstrate what it means to reflect God's character in daily life.
Leviticus 20: God prescribes severe penalties, often death, for serious violations including child sacrifice, consulting mediums, adultery, incest, and homosexual practice. These strict laws maintain Israel's holiness and distinguish them from the surrounding nations whose wickedness led to their expulsion from the land.
Leviticus 21: God establishes special holiness standards for priests, including restrictions on whom they may marry, when they may become ceremonially unclean, and physical requirements for those who serve at the altar. The high priest faces even stricter requirements because he represents the people before God.
Leviticus 22: God instructs priests to treat sacred offerings with respect and not profane His holy name. Regulations specify who may eat sacred food, what animals are acceptable for sacrifice, and when offerings may be presented to maintain the purity of worship.
Leviticus 23: God establishes Israel's sacred calendar with seven appointed festivals: the weekly Sabbath, Passover and Unleavened Bread, Firstfruits, Festival of Weeks (Pentecost), Festival of Trumpets, Day of Atonement, and Festival of Tabernacles. These festivals commemorate God's mighty acts and create a rhythm of worship throughout the year.
Leviticus 24: God commands that pure oil be used to keep the lamps burning continually in the tabernacle and that fresh bread be placed before the Lord each Sabbath. When a man blasphemes God's name, God establishes the death penalty for blasphemy and reaffirms the principle of proportional justice—eye for eye, tooth for tooth.
Leviticus 25: God institutes the Sabbath year (every seventh year) when the land must rest, and the Year of Jubilee (every fiftieth year) when all debts are cancelled, slaves freed, and land returned to original owners. These laws prevent permanent poverty and remind Israel that the land belongs to God.
Leviticus 26: God promises tremendous blessings for obedience—rain, abundant harvests, peace, victory over enemies, and His presence dwelling among them. However, God warns of severe consequences for disobedience, including disease, defeat, famine, exile, and desolation, though He promises never to completely destroy them or break His covenant.
Leviticus 27: God establishes regulations for making and fulfilling vows, including the valuation of people, animals, houses, and fields that are dedicated to the Lord. Tithes of crops and herds belong to the Lord and are holy, and if someone wishes to redeem what they've dedicated, they must add a fifth of its value.
Numbers 1: God commands Moses to take a census of all Israelite men twenty years old or older who can serve in the army, tribe by tribe. The Levites are excluded from the military census because they are set apart to care for the tabernacle and camp around it to protect the community from God's wrath.
Numbers 2: God arranges the twelve tribes in a specific formation around the tabernacle, with three tribes on each side—east, south, west, and north. The Levites camp in the middle around the tabernacle, and when the camp moves, they maintain this order with military precision.
Numbers 3: God sets apart the Levites to serve as substitutes for Israel's firstborn, who belong to God since He spared them in Egypt. The three Levite clans—Gershon, Kohath, and Merari—are assigned specific duties in caring for the tabernacle and its furnishings.
Numbers 4: God gives detailed instructions for how the Kohathites, Gershonites, and Merarites are to transport the tabernacle's sacred objects when the camp moves. The Kohathites carry the most holy things after Aaron and his sons have covered them, with death as the penalty for touching or looking at the sacred objects improperly.
Numbers 5: God commands that those with infectious diseases, bodily discharges, or who are ceremonially unclean be sent outside the camp to maintain purity. Laws are given for making restitution for wrongs, and a test is established for a wife suspected of adultery, involving drinking bitter water that brings a curse if she is guilty.
Numbers 6: God establishes regulations for the Nazirite vow, a special period of dedication involving abstaining from wine and grape products, not cutting one's hair, and avoiding dead bodies. God also gives Aaron the priestly blessing to pronounce over Israel: 'The Lord bless you and keep you; the Lord make his face shine on you...'
Numbers 7: The tribal leaders bring offerings for the dedication of the altar over twelve days, with each leader bringing identical gifts including silver and gold articles, animals for sacrifice, and grain offerings. Moses hears God's voice speaking to him from between the two cherubim above the ark's atonement cover.
Numbers 8: Aaron sets up the seven lamps in the tabernacle, and the Levites are ceremonially cleansed and presented as a wave offering before the Lord. The Levites replace the firstborn of Israel in serving at the tabernacle, working from age twenty-five to fifty.
Numbers 9: Israel celebrates the first Passover in the wilderness at God's command, with provision made for those who are ceremonially unclean to observe it one month later. God provides the pillar of cloud and fire to guide Israel's travels, and the people move or camp according to the cloud's movement over the tabernacle.
Numbers 10: God instructs Moses to make two silver trumpets for calling the community together, signaling to break camp, and sounding alarms. Israel sets out from Mount Sinai in organized formation, and Moses invites his brother-in-law Hobab to accompany them as a guide through the wilderness.
Numbers 11: The people complain about their hardships, angering God who sends fire among them. They crave meat and despise the manna, so God promises meat for a month until they're sick of it, and Moses receives seventy elders to help bear the burden of leadership as God's Spirit rests upon them.
Numbers 12: Miriam and Aaron speak against Moses because of his Cushite wife and question whether God speaks only through Moses. God rebukes them, affirming Moses' unique relationship with Him, and strikes Miriam with leprosy for seven days as punishment before healing her.
Numbers 13: God commands Moses to send twelve spies to explore Canaan, one leader from each tribe. After forty days, they return with abundant fruit but a divided report—ten spies describe giants and fortified cities saying the land devours its inhabitants, while Caleb and Joshua urge trust in God to give them victory.
Numbers 14: The Israelites rebel, weeping all night and wanting to return to Egypt, even threatening to stone Joshua and Caleb. God threatens to destroy Israel and start over with Moses, but Moses intercedes and God pardons them, though He decrees that this generation will wander forty years in the wilderness and not enter the Promised Land.
Numbers 15: God gives instructions for offerings once they enter the Promised Land, including grain and drink offerings accompanying sacrifices. Regulations for unintentional sins and a command to wear tassels on their garments as reminders to obey God's commands are established.
Numbers 16: Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and 250 leaders rebel against Moses and Aaron's authority, claiming the whole community is holy. God vindicates Moses' leadership by opening the earth to swallow the rebels and sending fire to consume the 250 men, then plaguing the community when they grumble the next day until Aaron's intercession stops it.
Numbers 17: To end the grumbling about Aaron's priesthood, God commands each tribe to provide a staff with the leader's name on it. Aaron's staff for Levi miraculously buds, blossoms, and produces almonds overnight, confirming God's choice of Aaron's family for the priesthood, and the staff is kept in the tabernacle as a lasting sign.
Numbers 18: God establishes that Aaron and his sons bear responsibility for offenses against the sanctuary, and He gives the Levites to them as a gift to perform tabernacle duties. The Levites receive the tithes from Israel as their inheritance since they have no land, and they must give a tenth of the tithes to the priests.
Numbers 19: God provides instructions for preparing the water of cleansing using the ashes of a red heifer without defect. This water purifies those who become unclean through contact with a dead body, requiring sprinkling on the third and seventh days before they can rejoin the community.
Numbers 20: Miriam dies and is buried at Kadesh. When the community lacks water and rebels, God tells Moses to speak to the rock, but Moses strikes it twice in anger and takes credit for the miracle, disqualifying himself from entering the Promised Land. Edom refuses passage through their territory, and Aaron dies on Mount Hor.
Numbers 21: God sends venomous snakes among the Israelites when they grumble, and many die until Moses makes a bronze snake that heals those who look at it. Israel defeats the Canaanite king of Arad, travels around Edom, and conquers the Amorite kings Sihon and Og, settling in their territory.
Numbers 22: Balak king of Moab sends for the diviner Balaam to curse Israel because he fears their numbers. God tells Balaam not to go, but when the messengers persist with greater honor, God allows it while warning him to speak only what God commands. God's angel opposes Balaam on the road, and his donkey sees the angel and speaks before Balaam's eyes are opened.
Numbers 23: Balaam prepares to curse Israel but can only speak blessings because God puts words in his mouth. Despite Balak's protests and moving to different locations, Balaam declares three times that Israel is blessed, that God is not a man that He should lie, and that no curse can stand against those whom God has blessed.
Numbers 24: The Spirit of God comes upon Balaam, and he prophesies a fourth blessing declaring Israel's future glory and the rise of a ruler from Jacob who will crush the nations. Balaam delivers oracles against Moab, Edom, and other nations, then returns home, angering Balak who sent for him to curse Israel.
Numbers 25: Israelite men commit sexual immorality with Moabite women and worship Baal of Peor, provoking God's anger. A plague kills 24,000 until Phinehas, Aaron's grandson, executes an Israelite man and Midianite woman in an act of zealous devotion to God, and God rewards Phinehas with a covenant of perpetual priesthood.
Numbers 26: God commands another census after the plague, counting 601,730 fighting men, showing a slight decrease from the first census. This new generation will inherit the land since the previous generation died in the wilderness, except for Caleb and Joshua who remained faithful.
Numbers 27: Zelophehad's daughters petition Moses for inheritance rights since their father died without sons, and God grants their request, establishing that daughters can inherit when there are no sons. God tells Moses to climb Mount Abarim to see the Promised Land before he dies, and Moses appoints Joshua as his successor.
Numbers 28: God reiterates the regulations for daily, Sabbath, monthly, and festival offerings that must be maintained throughout the generations. These include burnt offerings, grain offerings, and drink offerings for specific occasions to ensure continual worship and remembrance of God's appointed times.
Numbers 29: God provides detailed instructions for offerings during the Festival of Trumpets, Day of Atonement, and Festival of Tabernacles. The Festival of Tabernacles requires extensive sacrifices over seven days, with the number of bulls decreasing each day, demonstrating the costliness of worship and gratitude for God's provision.
Numbers 30: God establishes regulations for vows made by men and women, specifying when vows are binding and when they can be nullified. A father can nullify his daughter's vow, and a husband can nullify his wife's vow on the day he hears it, but a widow or divorced woman is bound by her vows.
Numbers 31: God commands Israel to take vengeance on the Midianites for leading them into sin at Peor. Israel defeats Midian, killing their kings and Balaam, and takes plunder, but Moses is angry they spared the women who had led Israel into sin, ordering them to purify themselves and divide the plunder according to God's instructions.
Numbers 32: The tribes of Reuben and Gad request to settle in the fertile land east of the Jordan because it's suitable for their large herds. Moses initially thinks they're abandoning their brothers, but when they agree to fight alongside Israel until the land is conquered, he grants their request along with half the tribe of Manasseh.
Numbers 33: Moses records all the stages of Israel's journey from Egypt through the wilderness to the plains of Moab. God commands them to drive out all the inhabitants of Canaan, destroy their idols, and distribute the land by lot among the tribes.
Numbers 34: God describes the boundaries of the Promised Land that Israel will inherit, from the Wilderness of Zin to Lebanon, and from the Mediterranean Sea to the Jordan River. God appoints Eleazar the priest and Joshua, along with one leader from each tribe, to assign the land inheritance.
Numbers 35: God commands Israel to give the Levites forty-eight towns with pasturelands since the Levites receive no territorial inheritance. Six of these towns must be cities of refuge where someone who accidentally kills another person can flee for protection from the avenger of blood until they stand trial before the assembly.
Numbers 36: The family heads of Gilead express concern that if Zelophehad's daughters marry outside their tribe, their inheritance will be transferred to another tribe. God commands that women who inherit land must marry within their father's tribal clan to keep the inheritance within the tribe, and Zelophehad's daughters obey this command.
Deuteronomy 1: Moses recounts how God commanded Israel to leave Mount Horeb and take possession of the Promised Land. He reminds them of appointing leaders, sending spies, the people's rebellion and refusal to enter the land, and God's judgment that the wilderness generation would not see the land except Caleb and Joshua.
Deuteronomy 2: Moses recalls Israel's wilderness wanderings, God's command not to fight the descendants of Esau or Lot, and the defeat of King Sihon of Heshbon. God gave Edom, Moab, and Ammon their lands and would not allow Israel to take them, but He delivered Sihon into Israel's hands.
Deuteronomy 3: Moses describes the defeat of Og king of Bashan and the distribution of the conquered territory to Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh. Moses pleads with God to let him enter the Promised Land, but God refuses because of his sin at Meribah, though He allows Moses to see it from Mount Pisgah.
Deuteronomy 4: Moses urges Israel to obey God's decrees and laws, remembering God's mighty acts and warnings not to make idols or worship other gods. He emphasizes that God is merciful and will not abandon His covenant people even when they are scattered in exile, and he sets apart three cities of refuge east of the Jordan.
Deuteronomy 5: Moses rehearses the Ten Commandments that God spoke at Mount Horeb, emphasizing that God made this covenant with the living generation, not just their fathers. The people asked Moses to be their mediator because they feared God's presence, and Moses urges them to obey so they may live long and prosper in the land.
Deuteronomy 6: Moses proclaims the Shema—'Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one'—commanding Israel to love God with all their heart, soul, and strength. Parents must teach God's commands diligently to their children, and Israel must not forget God when they prosper in the Promised Land.
Deuteronomy 7: God commands Israel to completely destroy the Canaanite nations, make no treaties with them, and show them no mercy because their wickedness would lead Israel into idolatry. God chose Israel not because they were numerous but because He loved them and kept His oath to their fathers, and He promises to bless them with health, fertility, and victory if they obey.
Deuteronomy 8: Moses warns Israel to remember their forty years in the wilderness where God humbled them, tested them, fed them with manna, and taught them that man does not live on bread alone but on every word from God's mouth. When they prosper in the Promised Land, they must not forget the Lord or think their own power gained them wealth.
Deuteronomy 9: Moses reminds Israel they are not entering the land because of their righteousness but because of the wickedness of the nations and God's covenant promises. He recounts their rebellion with the golden calf at Horeb and other times they provoked God, emphasizing that Moses' intercession alone saved them from destruction.
Deuteronomy 10: God gives Moses new stone tablets to replace those he broke, and Moses places them in the ark he made. Moses reminds Israel what God requires: to fear Him, walk in His ways, love Him, serve Him with all their heart, and keep His commands for their own good.
Deuteronomy 11: Moses calls Israel to love and obey the Lord, remembering the signs and wonders they saw in Egypt and the wilderness. If they obey, God will bless them with rain, abundant harvests, and victory; if they disobey and worship other gods, He will withhold rain and remove them from the land.
Deuteronomy 12: God commands Israel to destroy all pagan worship sites in the land and worship only at the place He chooses. They must not worship God in the way the nations worship their gods, and they are to bring their offerings and sacrifices to the central sanctuary, rejoicing before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 13: God warns against following prophets or dreamers who perform signs but lead people to worship other gods—they must be put to death. If a relative, friend, or an entire town entices people to idolatry, they must be destroyed to purge evil from Israel.
Deuteronomy 14: God reminds Israel they are His treasured possession, set apart to be holy. He repeats the dietary laws distinguishing clean from unclean animals and commands Israel to tithe annually and bring it to the place God chooses, using it for a joyful celebration before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 15: God institutes a Sabbath year when debts must be cancelled and Hebrew servants freed. Israel must be generous to the poor, lending freely without a grudging heart, knowing God will bless them for their obedience and care for the vulnerable.
Deuteronomy 16: God commands Israel to celebrate three annual pilgrimage festivals: Passover and Unleavened Bread, Festival of Weeks, and Festival of Tabernacles. All males must appear before the Lord three times a year, and judges and officials must be appointed to administer justice impartially.
Deuteronomy 17: God prohibits sacrificing defective animals and commands that idolaters be stoned to death on the testimony of two or three witnesses. Instructions for future kings emphasize that the king must be chosen by God, not accumulate wealth or wives, and must write a copy of God's law and read it daily to fear the Lord and obey His commands.
Deuteronomy 18: The Levitical priests receive their inheritance from offerings and tithes since they have no land. God forbids detestable practices like child sacrifice, divination, and sorcery, promising to raise up a prophet like Moses who will speak God's words—a false prophet who speaks presumptuously or in other gods' names must die.
Deuteronomy 19: God commands Israel to set apart three cities of refuge in the Promised Land where someone who accidentally kills another can flee for safety. Additional cities must be added as the territory expands, and intentional murderers must not find refuge but be put to death. False witnesses must receive the punishment they intended for the accused.
Deuteronomy 20: God provides laws for warfare, including who is exempt from fighting, how to offer peace to distant cities, and how to conduct siege warfare. Israel must completely destroy the Canaanite nations to prevent them from teaching detestable practices, but they must not destroy fruit trees during sieges.
Deuteronomy 21: If a murder victim is found and the killer is unknown, the elders of the nearest town must perform a ritual to atone for the bloodshed. Laws cover marrying female captives, rights of the firstborn son even if from an unloved wife, dealing with rebellious sons, and proper burial of executed criminals.
Deuteronomy 22: God establishes various laws promoting community care, sexual purity, and distinct gender roles. These include helping with lost animals, not wearing clothes of the opposite sex, protecting bird mothers, building safe roofs, not mixing seeds or fabrics, wearing tassels, and severe penalties for sexual immorality and false accusations.
Deuteronomy 23: God establishes who may enter the assembly of the Lord, excluding those with certain physical conditions, Ammonites, and Moabites, but allowing third-generation Edomites and Egyptians. Laws promote camp cleanliness, protection for runaway slaves, prohibition of shrine prostitution, regulations on vows, and permission to eat from neighbors' fields without harvesting.
Deuteronomy 24: God regulates divorce, prohibiting remarriage to a former wife if she married someone else in between. Laws protect newlyweds, prohibit taking millstones as pledges, require fair treatment of workers, limit punishment, mandate gleaning rights for the poor, and emphasize individual responsibility for sin.
Deuteronomy 25: God limits flogging to forty lashes, prohibits muzzling oxen while treading grain, and establishes levirate marriage where a brother must marry his deceased brother's widow to preserve his name. Laws address honest weights and measures, and God commands Israel to destroy the Amalekites for attacking them when they were weak.
Deuteronomy 26: When Israel enters the land, they must bring firstfruits to the priest and recite how God delivered them from Egypt and brought them to this land flowing with milk and honey. Every third year they must declare they've properly distributed tithes to the Levites, foreigners, fatherless, and widows, and God will establish them as His holy people if they obey.
Deuteronomy 27: Moses commands Israel to set up large stones covered with plaster on Mount Ebal and write God's law on them when they cross the Jordan. They must build an altar there and pronounce curses from Mount Ebal for disobedience while the Levites declare twelve specific curses that the people must affirm with 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 28: God promises extraordinary blessings for obedience—prosperity, fertility, victory over enemies, and favor in everything. However, He warns of devastating curses for disobedience—disease, drought, defeat, madness, oppression, and ultimately exile to a foreign land where they will serve other gods made of wood and stone.
Deuteronomy 29: Moses reminds Israel of God's faithfulness throughout their journey and calls them to enter into God's covenant. He warns that no one should think they can sin with impunity, for God's fierce anger will fall on them, and future generations will ask why the Lord brought such disaster upon the land.
Deuteronomy 30: Moses prophesies that after exile and curses, if Israel returns to the Lord with all their heart, He will restore their fortunes and gather them from the nations. God will circumcise their hearts to love Him, and obedience leads to life and prosperity while disobedience leads to death and destruction—the choice is theirs.
Deuteronomy 31: Moses, now 120 years old, announces he will not cross the Jordan, and Joshua will lead Israel into the land. Moses writes down the law and commands it to be read every seven years, and God tells Moses he will soon die, warning that Israel will abandon the covenant and worship other gods.
Deuteronomy 32: Moses recites a song testifying against Israel's future unfaithfulness, praising God's perfect faithfulness and justice while condemning the people's foolishness in forsaking their Rock. The song prophesies judgment but also promises that God will vindicate His people and have compassion on His servants when their strength is gone.
Deuteronomy 33: Moses blesses each tribe of Israel before his death, similar to Jacob's blessing of his sons. He declares the Lord's majesty, love for His people, and unique relationship with Israel, ending with a declaration that there is no one like the God of Israel who rides the heavens to help them.
Deuteronomy 34: Moses ascends Mount Nebo and views the Promised Land before he dies at age 120 with his eyes undimmed and strength unabated. God buries Moses in an unknown location in Moab, Israel mourns for thirty days, and Joshua is filled with wisdom to lead the people. No prophet has arisen in Israel like Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face.
Joshua 1: After Moses' death, God commissions Joshua to lead Israel across the Jordan into the Promised Land, promising to be with him as He was with Moses. God commands Joshua to be strong and courageous, meditating on the law day and night, and Joshua prepares the people to cross the Jordan in three days.
Joshua 2: Joshua sends two spies to explore Jericho, and they lodge with Rahab, a prostitute who hides them from the king's men. Rahab confesses faith in Israel's God and makes the spies promise to spare her family when they conquer the city, and she helps them escape by lowering them from her window with a scarlet cord.
Joshua 3: The priests carrying the Ark of the Covenant step into the Jordan River, and God miraculously stops the water upstream, allowing all Israel to cross on dry ground. This miracle demonstrates to Israel and the surrounding nations that the Lord is with Joshua as He was with Moses.
Joshua 4: God commands Joshua to have twelve men take stones from the Jordan riverbed to set up as a memorial at their camp in Gilgal. These stones serve as a permanent reminder for future generations of how God stopped the Jordan's flow so Israel could cross into the Promised Land.
Joshua 5: The Canaanite kings hear of the Jordan crossing and their hearts melt with fear. God commands Joshua to circumcise the generation born in the wilderness, Israel celebrates Passover at Gilgal, the manna ceases as they eat the produce of Canaan, and Joshua encounters the commander of the Lord's army who tells him to remove his sandals on holy ground.
Joshua 6: God gives Joshua specific instructions to march around Jericho once a day for six days, then seven times on the seventh day. When the priests blow the trumpets and the people shout, the walls collapse, Israel captures the city, and Rahab and her family are spared as promised.
Joshua 7: Israel is defeated at Ai because Achan secretly took devoted items from Jericho, bringing God's anger upon the whole nation. Joshua tears his clothes and falls before the Lord, who reveals Achan's sin, and after Achan confesses, he and his family are stoned and burned in the Valley of Achor.
Joshua 8: God tells Joshua not to be afraid but to take all the fighting men and capture Ai using an ambush strategy. Israel sets fire to the city, defeats its army, and Joshua builds an altar on Mount Ebal where he reads all the words of the law to the assembled people.
Joshua 9: The Gibeonites deceive Joshua by pretending to be from a distant land, wearing worn-out clothes and carrying moldy bread. Israel makes a peace treaty with them without consulting the Lord, and when the deception is discovered three days later, Israel honors the treaty but makes the Gibeonites woodcutters and water carriers for the community.
Joshua 10: Five Amorite kings attack Gibeon for making peace with Israel, and Joshua marches all night to rescue them. God throws the enemy into confusion, hurls large hailstones from the sky, and makes the sun stand still so Israel can complete the victory, then Joshua conquers the southern cities of Canaan.
Joshua 11: Northern Canaanite kings unite their armies to fight Israel, but God tells Joshua not to be afraid. Joshua attacks suddenly, defeats them all, hamstrings their horses, burns their chariots, and captures their cities, taking a long time to complete the conquest of the land.
Joshua 12: This chapter lists the thirty-one kings that Moses and Joshua defeated on both sides of the Jordan River. The summary records Israel's complete victory over the inhabitants of the land God promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Joshua 13: Though Joshua is old, much land remains to be conquered. God commands Joshua to divide the land among the nine and a half tribes, while acknowledging that Moses already gave inheritance to Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh on the east side of the Jordan.
Joshua 14: Caleb, now 85 years old, reminds Joshua that Moses promised him the hill country of Hebron because he followed the Lord wholeheartedly when they spied out the land forty-five years earlier. Joshua blesses Caleb and gives him Hebron as his inheritance.
Joshua 15: The territory allotted to the tribe of Judah is described in detail, including its boundaries and major cities. Caleb drives out the three Anakites from Hebron and captures Debir, giving his daughter Aksah in marriage to Othniel who conquers Kiriath Sepher, though Judah cannot dislodge the Jebusites from Jerusalem.
Joshua 16: The land allotment for the descendants of Joseph—Ephraim and Manasseh—is described, showing the borders of Ephraim's territory. However, Ephraim fails to drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, allowing them to live among them as forced laborers.
Joshua 17: The tribe of Manasseh receives its inheritance on both sides of the Jordan, with special provision made for Zelophehad's daughters as Moses commanded. The descendants of Joseph complain they have too little land, and Joshua challenges them to clear the forested hill country if they need more space.
Joshua 18: The whole Israelite assembly gathers at Shiloh and sets up the Tent of Meeting, but seven tribes have not yet received their inheritance. Joshua appoints men to survey the remaining land and divide it into seven parts, then he casts lots before the Lord at Shiloh to determine each tribe's territory, beginning with Benjamin.
Joshua 19: The remaining six tribes—Simeon, Zebulun, Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Dan—receive their land allotments by lot. After all the tribes have received their inheritance, the Israelites give Joshua the town of Timnath Serah in the hill country of Ephraim as his personal inheritance.
Joshua 20: God commands Joshua to designate six cities of refuge—three on each side of the Jordan—where someone who accidentally kills another person can flee for protection. The person must stand trial before the assembly, and if found innocent of murder, may live safely in the city until the high priest's death.
Joshua 21: The Levites receive forty-eight towns with pasturelands from the other tribes' territories, as Moses commanded. The Kohathites receive towns in Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, the Gershonites in northern tribes, and the Merarites in the east, and the Lord gives Israel rest on every side as He promised their ancestors.
Joshua 22: Joshua commends the eastern tribes—Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh—for their faithful service and sends them home with his blessing. When they build a large altar by the Jordan, the western tribes fear it signals rebellion against God, but the eastern tribes explain it's merely a memorial witness, and peace is maintained.
Joshua 23: Many years later, Joshua gathers Israel's leaders and reminds them of all God has done, driving out great nations before them. He urges them to be strong, obey the law, avoid the remaining nations and their gods, and warns that if they turn away from the Lord, He will bring disaster upon them and drive them from the good land.
Joshua 24: Joshua assembles all Israel at Shechem and recounts their history from Abraham through the conquest. He challenges them to choose whom they will serve, declaring 'as for me and my household, we will serve the Lord,' and the people affirm their commitment to serve God alone, renewing the covenant before Joshua dies at age 110.
Judges 1: After Joshua's death, Judah and Simeon fight together to conquer their allotted territory, achieving significant victories. However, most tribes fail to drive out the Canaanites completely, instead allowing them to live among them as forced laborers, setting the stage for future problems.
Judges 2: The angel of the Lord rebukes Israel for making treaties with the inhabitants of the land and not tearing down their altars. After Joshua's generation dies, a new generation arises that does not know the Lord, and Israel enters a cycle of sin, oppression, crying out, and deliverance through judges God raises up.
Judges 3: The Lord leaves certain nations in Canaan to test Israel, but Israel intermarries with them and serves their gods. God raises up three judges: Othniel defeats Cushan-Rishathaim, Ehud assassinates the obese Moabite king Eglon, and Shamgar strikes down six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad.
Judges 4: After Ehud dies, Israel again does evil and God sells them to Jabin king of Canaan who oppresses them for twenty years. Deborah the prophetess and judge summons Barak to fight Sisera's army, promising God will give them victory, but because Barak insists Deborah come with him, a woman—Jael—gets the honor of killing Sisera.
Judges 5: Deborah and Barak sing a victory song celebrating how God fought for Israel, praising those tribes who helped and condemning those who stayed away. They honor Jael for her courage in killing Sisera, and the land has peace for forty years.
Judges 6: Israel does evil again, and God gives them into the hands of Midian for seven years. The angel of the Lord appears to Gideon and calls him to deliver Israel, though Gideon protests his weakness, and God gives him signs including fire consuming his offering and dew on a fleece to confirm his calling.
Judges 7: God reduces Gideon's army from 32,000 to 300 men so Israel cannot boast that their own strength saved them. Using trumpets, torches, and jars, Gideon's small force throws the Midianite camp into confusion at night, and they flee while Israel pursues and defeats them.
Judges 8: The Ephraimites quarrel with Gideon for not calling them to fight Midian, but he appeases them with gentle words. Gideon pursues and captures the Midianite kings Zebah and Zalmunna, executes them, and refuses to become Israel's king, though he makes a golden ephod that becomes a snare to Israel.
Judges 9: After Gideon dies, his son Abimelech murders his seventy brothers to become king, but the youngest, Jotham, escapes and pronounces a curse. Abimelech rules for three years before God sends an evil spirit between him and the citizens of Shechem, and Abimelech dies when a woman drops a millstone on his head during a siege.
Judges 10: Tola judges Israel for twenty-three years, followed by Jair for twenty-two years. Israel again does evil, serving foreign gods, and God allows the Philistines and Ammonites to oppress them for eighteen years until they cry out and put away their foreign gods.
Judges 11: Jephthah, son of a prostitute and rejected by his brothers, is called back to lead Israel against the Ammonites. He negotiates with the Ammonite king, makes a rash vow to God, defeats Ammon, and tragically must sacrifice his daughter to fulfill his vow.
Judges 12: The Ephraimites again quarrel over not being called to battle, but this time Jephthah fights them, and 42,000 Ephraimites die. Jephthah judges Israel for six years, followed by Ibzan, Elon, and Abdon who together judge for twenty-five years.
Judges 13: Israel does evil again, and God gives them to the Philistines for forty years. The angel of the Lord appears to Manoah's barren wife, announcing she will bear a son who must be a Nazirite from birth and will begin to deliver Israel from the Philistines—this son is Samson.
Judges 14: Samson insists on marrying a Philistine woman from Timnah despite his parents' objections, though the Lord is using this to confront the Philistines. At his wedding feast, Samson poses a riddle, his wife betrays the answer to her people, and in anger Samson kills thirty Philistines and his wife is given to his best man.
Judges 15: Samson returns for his wife and learns she's been given to another, so he burns the Philistines' crops by tying torches to foxes' tails. The Philistines burn his wife and father-in-law, Samson slaughters many Philistines, and when Judah binds him to hand him over, he breaks free and kills a thousand Philistines with a donkey's jawbone.
Judges 16: Samson falls in love with Delilah, and the Philistines bribe her to discover the secret of his strength. After three failed attempts, Samson finally reveals that his strength lies in his uncut hair, and while he sleeps, Delilah has his hair cut, the Philistines capture him, gouge out his eyes, and imprison him to grind grain.
Judges 17: A man named Micah steals silver from his mother, returns it, and she uses it to make an idol. Micah builds a shrine, makes an ephod, and appoints his son as priest, then hires a wandering Levite to be his personal priest, believing this will bring God's blessing despite his blatant idolatry.
Judges 18: The Danites, seeking territory, send spies who visit Micah's house and inquire of his Levite priest. The spies recommend the city of Laish, and on their way to conquer it, 600 Danites steal Micah's idols and hire away his priest, who becomes their tribal priest despite protests from Micah.
Judges 19: A Levite's concubine leaves him, and when he retrieves her, they stop for the night in Gibeah of Benjamin. Wicked men demand to abuse the Levite, but he gives them his concubine, and they abuse her all night until she dies, and the Levite cuts her into twelve pieces and sends them throughout Israel.
Judges 20: All Israel gathers in response to the atrocity at Gibeah and demands Benjamin hand over the guilty men, but Benjamin refuses and goes to war to defend them. After two costly defeats where Israel loses 40,000 men, they finally defeat Benjamin, killing 25,000 warriors and nearly wiping out the entire tribe.
Judges 21: Israel regrets destroying Benjamin and seeks to preserve the tribe since they vowed not to give their daughters in marriage to Benjamin. They attack Jabesh Gilead for not joining the battle, giving the virgins to Benjamin, and allow Benjamin to kidnap women at the festival in Shiloh, concluding with the refrain that everyone did what was right in their own eyes.
Ruth 1: During a famine, Elimelech takes his wife Naomi and two sons to Moab, where his sons marry Moabite women, Ruth and Orpah. After all three men die, Naomi decides to return to Bethlehem, and though she urges her daughters-in-law to stay in Moab, Ruth clings to her with beautiful words of commitment: 'Where you go I will go, and where you stay I will stay. Your people will be my people and your God my God.'
Ruth 2: Ruth goes to glean grain in the fields and happens to work in a field belonging to Boaz, a relative of Elimelech. Boaz shows her extraordinary kindness, ensuring her safety, providing extra grain, and inviting her to eat with his workers, and when Naomi learns of this, she recognizes Boaz as their kinsman-redeemer.
Ruth 3: Following Naomi's instructions, Ruth goes to the threshing floor at night, uncovers Boaz's feet, and lies down. When Boaz wakes, Ruth asks him to spread his garment over her as a kinsman-redeemer, and Boaz praises her loyalty, promising to redeem her though there is a closer relative who has first rights.
Ruth 4: Boaz goes to the town gate and negotiates with the closer relative, who initially wants to redeem Elimelech's land but backs out when he learns it includes marrying Ruth. Boaz redeems the land and marries Ruth, and she bears a son Obed, who becomes the grandfather of King David, placing Ruth in the messianic line.
1 Samuel 1: Hannah, one of Elkanah's two wives, is barren and deeply grieved while Peninnah taunts her for having no children. Hannah prays desperately at Shiloh, vowing to give her son to the Lord's service, and Eli the priest blesses her, and God remembers her and she conceives Samuel.
1 Samuel 2: Hannah praises God with a beautiful prayer celebrating His sovereignty, and after weaning Samuel, she brings him to serve the Lord at Shiloh under Eli. Meanwhile, Eli's sons are wicked, treating the Lord's offering with contempt and sleeping with women at the tabernacle entrance, and a prophet warns Eli that his family line will be judged.
1 Samuel 3: The boy Samuel ministers before the Lord under Eli when the word of the Lord was rare and visions uncommon. The Lord calls Samuel three times in the night, and when Eli realizes it's the Lord, he tells Samuel to respond, and God reveals to Samuel that He will judge Eli's family as He warned.
1 Samuel 4: Israel goes to battle against the Philistines, suffers a defeat, and brings the Ark of the Covenant from Shiloh, thinking it will ensure victory. The Philistines fight harder, defeat Israel again, capture the ark, kill Eli's two sons, and when Eli hears the news, he falls backward, breaks his neck, and dies.
1 Samuel 5: The Philistines place the captured ark in the temple of their god Dagon, but Dagon falls before it twice, and God afflicts the people of Ashdod and other cities with tumors. After seven months of plagues, the Philistines send the ark back to Israel with a guilt offering of gold tumors and rats.
1 Samuel 6: The Philistines place the ark on a cart pulled by two cows that have never been yoked, and the cows head straight to Beth Shemesh without turning. The people of Beth Shemesh rejoice but 70 men die when they look into the ark, and they send it to Kiriath Jearim where it remains for twenty years.
1 Samuel 7: Samuel calls Israel to repentance at Mizpah, and they put away their foreign gods and serve the Lord alone. When the Philistines attack during their gathering, God throws them into confusion with thunder, Israel defeats them, and Samuel sets up a stone memorial called Ebenezer, and judges Israel all his days.
1 Samuel 8: When Samuel grows old, he appoints his sons as judges, but they are corrupt, taking bribes and perverting justice. The elders demand a king to be like other nations, and though Samuel warns them about the king's demands, they insist, and God tells Samuel to give them a king.
1 Samuel 9: Saul, a handsome young man from Benjamin, searches for his father's lost donkeys and comes to Samuel the seer for help. God has already revealed to Samuel that Saul is the one He has chosen to be king over Israel, and Samuel anoints him privately and tells him the donkeys have been found.
1 Samuel 10: Samuel anoints Saul as king, gives him signs that are fulfilled, and the Spirit of the Lord comes upon him. Samuel gathers the people at Mizpah, publicly confirms Saul as king through casting lots, and though Saul is hiding among the baggage, they bring him out and the people shout 'Long live the king!'
1 Samuel 11: Nahash the Ammonite besieges Jabesh Gilead and threatens to gouge out everyone's right eye. When Saul hears the news, the Spirit of God comes upon him powerfully, he musters Israel's army, defeats the Ammonites decisively, and the people go to Gilgal to reaffirm Saul's kingship.
1 Samuel 12: Samuel addresses all Israel, affirming his integrity as judge and reviewing how God delivered them repeatedly despite their unfaithfulness. He rebukes them for demanding a king but assures them God will not abandon them if they fear and serve Him, and God sends thunder and rain during harvest to demonstrate His displeasure.
1 Samuel 13: Saul's son Jonathan attacks a Philistine outpost, provoking war, and the Philistines assemble a massive army. When Samuel delays coming to Gilgal and the soldiers begin to scatter, Saul presumptuously offers the burnt offering himself, and Samuel arrives immediately after, rebuking Saul and declaring that his kingdom will not endure.
1 Samuel 14: Without telling his father, Jonathan and his armor-bearer climb up to a Philistine outpost and God gives them a great victory. Saul makes a rash oath that no one may eat until evening, Jonathan unknowingly violates it, and though Saul intends to kill him, the people intervene and rescue Jonathan.
1 Samuel 15: God commands Saul to completely destroy the Amalekites and everything they have, but Saul spares King Agag and the best animals, claiming he intends to sacrifice them to the Lord. Samuel confronts Saul, declaring that to obey is better than sacrifice, and God has rejected Saul as king because of his rebellion, then Samuel kills Agag himself.
1 Samuel 16: God sends Samuel to Bethlehem to anoint one of Jesse's sons as the next king. Samuel anoints David, the youngest, who was tending sheep, and the Spirit of the Lord comes upon him, while the Spirit departs from Saul and an evil spirit torments him, and David is brought to play the harp to soothe Saul.
1 Samuel 17: The Philistine champion Goliath challenges Israel for forty days, and young David, bringing food to his brothers at the battle lines, volunteers to fight him. David refuses Saul's armor, takes five smooth stones and his sling, declares he comes in the name of the Lord, and kills Goliath with one stone, then cuts off his head with the giant's own sword.
1 Samuel 18: Jonathan becomes deeply attached to David and makes a covenant with him, and David succeeds in everything Saul sends him to do. The women's song 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his tens of thousands' enrages Saul, who tries twice to pin David to the wall with a spear, then schemes to have him killed by the Philistines by requiring him to kill 100 Philistines for his daughter Michal.
1 Samuel 19: Saul openly orders his son and servants to kill David, but Jonathan warns David and intercedes, temporarily changing his father's mind. When Saul tries again to pin David to the wall with his spear, Michal helps David escape through a window, and Saul sends messengers to arrest him, but the Spirit of God comes upon them and they prophesy instead.
1 Samuel 20: David meets secretly with Jonathan to determine if Saul truly intends to kill him. They devise a plan using arrows as a signal, and when Saul's anger explodes at Jonathan for defending David, Jonathan confirms that David must flee, and the two friends weep together and renew their covenant before parting.
1 Samuel 21: David flees to Nob where he deceives Ahimelech the priest, takes the consecrated bread, and receives Goliath's sword. He then escapes to Gath where he feigns insanity before King Achish to save his life.
1 Samuel 22: David gathers his family and about 400 distressed, indebted, and discontented men at the cave of Adullam. Saul, learning that Ahimelech helped David, has Doeg the Edomite massacre 85 priests and destroy the entire town of Nob, but one priest, Abiathar, escapes to David.
1 Samuel 23: David rescues the town of Keilah from the Philistines, but when he learns through the ephod that the people will betray him to Saul, he flees to the Desert of Ziph. Jonathan finds David there and encourages him, reaffirming their covenant, and though the Ziphites betray David's location to Saul, a Philistine raid forces Saul to break off his pursuit.
1 Samuel 24: Saul enters a cave to relieve himself, unaware that David and his men are hiding deep inside. David's men urge him to kill Saul, but David only cuts off a corner of Saul's robe and afterward feels guilty even for that, and when David reveals himself, Saul weeps, acknowledging David's righteousness and that he will be king.
1 Samuel 25: Samuel dies and all Israel mourns. The wealthy but churlish Nabal refuses to help David's men despite their protection of his shepherds, and David prepares to kill every male in Nabal's household, but Nabal's wise wife Abigail intercepts him with abundant provisions, and David blesses her for keeping him from bloodshed, then Nabal dies and David marries Abigail.
1 Samuel 26: The Ziphites again betray David's location to Saul. David and Abishai sneak into Saul's camp at night, and though Abishai wants to kill Saul, David refuses to harm the Lord's anointed, taking only Saul's spear and water jug as proof, and Saul again admits his sin and blesses David.
1 Samuel 27: David, thinking Saul will eventually kill him, takes refuge with King Achish of Gath along with his 600 men and their families. David deceives Achish by raiding Israel's enemies but claiming to attack Judah, and Achish believes David has become odious to his people and will serve him forever.
1 Samuel 28: The Philistines gather to fight Israel, and Saul, terrified, seeks God's guidance but receives no answer. In desperation, Saul disguises himself and visits a medium at Endor, who brings up Samuel's spirit, and Samuel prophesies that the Lord has torn the kingdom from Saul and tomorrow he and his sons will die in battle.
1 Samuel 29: The Philistine commanders object to David joining them in battle against Israel, not trusting him despite Achish's confidence. Achish reluctantly sends David away, and David returns to Ziklag while the Philistines march to fight Israel.
1 Samuel 30: David and his men return to Ziklag to find the Amalekites have raided, burned the town, and taken all the women and children captive. David's men talk of stoning him, but David strengthens himself in the Lord, pursues the raiders, recovers everything, and establishes a rule that those who guard supplies share equally in the plunder.
1 Samuel 31: The Philistines defeat Israel on Mount Gilboa, and Saul's three sons, including Jonathan, are killed. Saul is badly wounded by archers, falls on his own sword to avoid capture, and his armor-bearer does the same, and the next day the Philistines find their bodies, cut off Saul's head, and fastened his body to the wall of Beth Shan until the men of Jabesh Gilead retrieve and bury them.
